HISTORY.

——0-0p 00—

THE State of Maryland was one of the British

colonies, and original thirteen States of the
American Union, and occupies the most central po-
sition on the seaboard, nearly surrounding the Na-
tional Capital.

The first settlement in Maryland was made in 1631
upon Kent Island, by William Claiborne and some
followers, who took possession of that region. In
the following year, a grant was made by Charles L
of England, to Lord Baltimore, of lands covering an
area even larger than the present limits of the State.
A permanent settlement was made and government
established at St. Mary’s, on the river and in the
county of the same name, at the head of which col-
ony was Leonard Calvert, the brother of the Propri-
etary. The name of Maryland (Terra Marize) was
given in honor of the queen of the reigning mon-
arch, Charles I. The first settlers were Catholic
refugees. The settlers on Kent Island refused alle-
giance, and gave some trouble, but were finally
brought into subjection to the Proprietary’s govern-
ment. The colony in its younger days underwent
many changes, the Proprietary being displaced at
times, and the British government appointing gov-
ernors. In 1691, the British king, who had assumed
control of the colony, appointed Sir Lionel Copley
governor, and one of the first acts of his government
was the removal of the seat of government from
St. Mary’s to the town of Providence, from that time
called Annapolis, where it has ever since remained.
In this locality was concentrated the Puritan ele-
ment, which had now gained the ascendancy.

In 1715, the government was again and finally
restored to the Proprietary, the principal obstacle to
the recognition of the family rights being removed
by the fact of their having been educated in the faith
of the establizhed “ Church of England.” The pop-
ulation was then about 80,600, and at this time and
very many years succeeding, tobacco was almost the
only production, and was also used as a currency for
various purposes, and mostly in trade. In 1745, the
first and for a long time the only newspaper in the
colony, the “ Maryland Gazette,” was published at
Annapolis. In 1748, the population was estimated
at 130,000, of which 94,000 were white, and 36,000
colored. In the contest which annihilated the French
dominion in America, Maryland took an active part.

The unfortunate expedition of Braddock against
Fort Duquesne was organized in this Province, and
marched from Frederick in 1754. In the Revolu-

- tion, Maryland also occupied a leading position, par-

ticipating early and strenuously in all the move-
ments of that period. The province expended nearly
$8,000,000 and furnished over 20,000 men to the
armies. At the close of the war, Congress met in
the State House at Annapolis, and the Senate cham-
ber of that vencrable edifice (which is still un-
changed) became inseparably connected with the
history of that epoch, by the resignation therein of
his commission as commander-in-chief of the armies,
by George Washington.

In the war with Great Britain in 1812 and 1815,
many important movements of the British on land
and water took place in this State. In 1813, the vil-
lages of Frenchtown, Havre de Grace, Frederick-
town, and Georgetown, about the head of the Bay,
were plundered and burned by the naval force of
Admiral Cockburn, which traversed the Chesapeake.
The battle of Bladensburg was fought near the town
of the same name, and resulted disastrously to the
American forces. In 1814, the British attempted the
attack upon Baltimore city, which ended in their
defeat at the battle of North Point in Patapsco

‘Neck, and they were also completely repulsed in

their direct attack on the city by Fort McHenry and

some small batteries on the suburbs of the town.
At the November session of the Assembly in 1835,

an Act was passed amending the Constitution and



HISTORY.

form of government of the State. It gave the elec-
tion of the governor to the people, instead of to two
eléctors from each county as heretofore; abolished
the Council to the Governor; gave one senator to
each county and one to the city of Baltimore, and
changed the apportionment of delegates, giving five
to Baltimore and to each of two of the counties, four
to each of cight of the counties, three to cach of the
remaining counties, and one to Annapolis.

In 1851 a State Convention assembled for the pur-
pose of revising the Constitution. The principal
changes were: conforming the representations of
the counlies more to the population,— giving Balti-
more city ten; to Anmapolis, none; to two of the
counties, six; to one, five; to two, four; to six,
three; and to the remaining ones, two each; making
the judiciary elective by the people, and making the
sessions of the legislature biennial.

Governor Lowe was succeeded in 1854 by T. Wat-
kins Ligon, Esq., of Howard County. IIe was suc-
ceeded, in 1857, by Thomas Holliday Iicks, Esq.,
of Dorchester County. During Governor Iicks’s
term of office, the Southern States seceded from the
Union.

The civil war virtually commenced on the 4th of
March, 1861, when Gen. P. T. Beauregard took for-
mal command of the Confederate forces in Charles-
ton, and commenced operations for besieging Fort
Sumter, which surrendered on the 13th of April fol-
lowing. Although Maryland did not secede from the
Union, some of the opening and most important
events of the war transpired in the State, the first
blood being shed in the streets of Baltimore on the
19th of April, when a Massachusetts regiment pass-
ing through to Washington was attacked by a mob,
and two Kkilled and eight wounded.

For some months after, the principal seat of war
being near Washington and on the Potomac border,
the proximity of large bodies of troops, and the con-
stant liability that the State would become the the-
atre of active hostilities, had a tendency to demoral-
ize all industries and keep the community in a state
of excitement and alarm, which subsequent events
fully justified, as Maryland was, during the war,
three times invaded by the Confederate forces.

In 1862, Gen. Lee passed northward through Vir-
ginia, forded the Potomac near the Point of Rocks
on the 8d of Sept., and on the morning of Sept.
6th, the advance-guard, 3,000 strong, under ¢ Stone-
wall” Jackson, entered without opposition the city
of Frederick. On the 8th, Gen. Lee issued a pro-
clamation to the people of Maryland, urging them
to secede from the Union, and assuring them of the
covperation of his army to aid them in severing
their connection with it. No general response was
made to the appeal. :

At the same time, Governor Augustus W. Brad-
ford, who succeeded Governor Hicks in December,
1861, issued a proclamation calling upon the citizens
to form suitable organizations to render effectual
aid to the National Government. On the 10th, the
advance of Gen. Lee’s army entered Ilagerstown,
having evacuated Frederick the same day, the latter
place being reached by the Union army under Gen.
McClellan on the 12th.

Gen. Lee having dispatched a portion of his army
under the command of Gen. Jackson, for the attack
on Harper’s Ferry, took up a strong position with the
remainder about twelve miles west of Frederick,
where, on the 14th, was fought the battle of South
Mountain, which was opened by an attack from the
right wing of the Union army under Gen. Hooker,
and, after a sharply contested engagement which
lasted throughout the day, the Confederate forces re-
treated in the direction of the Potomac, and concen-
trated at Sharpsburg, near Antietam Creek, where
they were rejoined by Gen. Jackson, who had, on the
15th, captured Harper’s Ferry with 11,000 prisoners.

Here, at daylight on the 17th of September, com-
menced the battle of ¢ Antietam,” one of the most
destructive engagements of the war, nearly 30,000



11

men being killed or wounded. About 200,000
men were engaged, with 500 pieces of artillery, the
fight continuing until the combatants were separated
by the darkness of the night. The tide of battle
swayed with varying results during the day, nearly
all the ground upon which it was fought being taken
and retaken in turn. Both armies slept upon the
field, expecting to renew the fight on the morning
of the 18th. The Confederate army, however, re-
tired from their position, and crossed the Potomac
into Virginia, abandoning every place they had occu-
pied north of the river, including Harper’s Ferry.

On the 10th and 11th of October following, Gen.
J. E. B. Stewart, with a force of 2,000 Confederate
cavalry, made a daring raid across the State, reach-
ing Chambersburg, P’a., where he burnt all the
Government property, supplied himself with fresh
horses, and, after capturing a large amount of stores
and supplies, passed rapidly around the Union army
in Maryland, and crossed the Potomac into Virginia.

On the 14th of June, 1863, Gen. Lee again crossed
the Potomac and advanced upon Hagerstown, ex-
tending his army through the border counties of
Maryland and Pennsylvania to Chambersburg, Car-
lisle, etc. The armies finally concentrated near
Gettysburg, a small town in Adams County, Pa.,
114 miles west of Philadelphia, and 75 north of
‘Washington.

Here, on the 1st, 2d, and 3d of July, was fought a
great battle between the entire army of Gen. Lee, and
the army of the Potomac under Gen. Meade, which
resulted in the defeat of the Confederate forces, and
a joint loss of about 48,000 men, killed or wounded.

In July, 1864, Gen. Early, with a force of 22,000
men, crossed the Potomac into Maryland, above
Harper’s Ferry, marched upon Hagerstown, and
took possession of that place. To save the city of
Frederick from burning, the sum of two hundred
thousand dollars was paid to General Early; and
nearly one hundred thousand dollars was paid to
McCausland, in money and goods, by the citizens of
Hagerstown.

Passing on towards Baltimore, he was met on the
9th of July by Gen. Lewis Wallace, at Monocacy,
where a severe engagement was had without check-
ing his advance, and the next day he took possession
of Fredericktown. For four days his army was en-
gaged in plundering the people of Maryland, passing
at one time to within six miles of Washington, cutting
the railroad and telegraphic communication with the
North, and threatening the Capital itself. On the 13th
he recrossed the Potomac with an immense amount
of booty, and made his way back to Richmond.

In April, 1864, a convention was held for a further
revision of the State Constitution. By this conven-
tion a registration of voters was provided for; the
principle of representation according to population
was adopted; to Baltimore City were given three
senators and eighteen representatives; to each county
one senator; to two counties six representatives; to
two, five; to two, four; to two, three; to two, eight;
and to four, one; the power of appointing magis-
trates was restored to the Governor; and a State
Board of Education was created, consisting of the
Governor, the Lieutenant-Governor, the Speaker of
the Iouse of Delegates, and the State Superinten-
dent of Education.

Besides these changes, it was declared — Article
24th, Declaration of Rights—¢that hereafter, in this
State, there shall be neither slavery nor involuntary
gervitude, except in punishment of crime whereof
the party shall have been duly convicted; and all
persons held to service or labor as slaves are hereby
declared free.”

Since the close of the Civil War, the advance of
Maryland in all material interests has been rapid.
An entire change in the system of labor, and the
establishment of free schools, have largely increased
immigration, and done much toward the develop-
ment of the agricultural and other industrial interests
of the State,
